title: Tyson Fury confident cuts will hold up in WWE debut vs Braun Strowman
text:
Fury suffered two deep gashes in his last fight (Picture: Reuters)

Several bangs to his eye during WWE training has Tyson Fury convinced there is no reason to be concerned about reopening a cut in his clash with Braun Strowman.

The Gypsy King takes on Strowman this Thursday just under seven weeks after suffering two serious cuts in his win over Otto Wallin.

Fury’s promoter Frank Warren reacted furiously to the news he would be making an appearance in WWE, branding the match an unnecessary risk that could jeopardise his rematch with Deontay Wilder.

That fight is booked for February, but Fury has repeatedly dismissed concerns about further damaging his eye ahead of a £11.9million pay day.

‘No concerns – Only about what I was going to wear on the day,’ was Fury’s response when asked if he had any doubts about linking up with the WWE during his recovery from two gashes.

‘I’ve had a couple bangs on the eye in training,’ he continued.

‘It seems to be holding up alright. I’ve been told one per cent each day.

‘Fifteen days of September and 25 days of October. Forty days… so sixty days left and I’m fully recovered.’

Fury is not expected to return to full contact training or resume sparring until the middle of December at the earliest, giving him just about enough time to prepare for his rematch with Wilder.

Any set-backs, however, could derail the February 22 fight date. Fury, 31, has spoken at length about how returning to boxing and working with coach Ben Davison essentially saved his life following a serious battle with depression.

Fury has taken on the WWE challenge during his recovery from injury (Picture: AP)

There were, however, concerns that after the gruelling encounter with Wallin that Fury was over-training. His father, John Fury, urged his son to axe his coaching team after the fight, suggesting his camp was at fault for the ‘weak’ performance against Wallin.

Fury, though, appears to have zero concerns about his lifestyle, revealing he was back in the gym the day after his win over Wallin.

‘I’ve got a lot to do. When you’re got five kids it’s a non-stop circus,’ Fury said.

‘It’s not the boxing training in that context, it’s just training physically on a daily basis [that I feel I have to do].

‘I train every day anyway. Even the day after the fight I was flat out in the gym with the cut.

‘I’m just not talking punches in boxing training. It’s just cardio and weights, strength training [at the moment].’

description: Tyson Fury insists his cut injury is holding up perfectly in WWE training after several bangs to the eye.
